note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with foreign body removal.
Indication: Suspected organic food aspiration with right middle lobe collapse.
Patient: 32-year-old female with no significant cardiopulmonary comorbidities who choked on mixed nuts at dinner and developed persistent cough and unilateral wheeze.
Sedation/airway: Moderate sedation with IV midazolam and fentanyl; native airway with oral bite block and supplemental oxygen by nasal cannula.
Procedure description: After standard time-out and topicalization of the oropharynx, a flexible video bronchoscope was advanced through the mouth. The trachea and main bronchi were patent. In the right middle lobe medial segment bronchus, a tan friable foreign body consistent with pistachio nut fragment was visualized, partially obstructing the lumen with adjacent mucosal edema. A 1.8 mm flexible retrieval basket was passed through the working channel, deployed distal to the foreign body, and closed to capture the fragment. The basket and bronchoscope were withdrawn en bloc. A small residual fragment was suctioned and removed on a second basket pass. No additional foreign material was seen after repeat inspection. No biopsies, lavage, or other therapeutic bronchoscopic interventions were performed.
Findings: Organic nut fragment obstructing the right middle lobe medial segment bronchus; mild mucosal erythema without active bleeding after removal.
Complications: None. No hypoxemia, arrhythmia, or clinically significant bleeding.
Disposition: Observed in PACU and discharged home the same day with return precautions.
Impression: Foreign body aspiration (organic nut fragment) status post complete removal via flexible bronchoscopy.

per_code.notes: 2025 national facility and office rates for 31635 from the airway fee schedule.

financial_analysis.notes: Single 31635 reported for bronchoscopic foreign body removal; no additional bronchoscopy CPT codes modeled.

bullets: Note documents flexible bronchoscopy with visualization and complete removal of an organic nut fragment from the right middle lobe bronchus, which is captured by 31635.
No bronchoscopic biopsies, lavage, airway ablation, or stent placement are described, so only 31635 is selected.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with foreign body removal.
Indication: Inorganic foreign body aspiration (denture fragment) with right lower lobe wheeze.
Patient: 68-year-old male with COPD who aspirated a partial denture while lying supine and developed persistent cough and focal right lower lobe wheeze.
Sedation/airway: Moderate sedation with IV midazolam and fentanyl; native airway with oral bite block and supplemental oxygen.
Procedure description: After informed consent and time-out, a flexible video bronchoscope was advanced through the mouth. The trachea, carina, and main bronchi were inspected and were without tumor or secretions. In the right lower lobe basal segment bronchus, a shiny metallic-appearing foreign body consistent with a denture clasp was lodged eccentrically, partially obstructing the lumen. Under brief fluoroscopic guidance, a flexible alligator forceps was passed through the working channel and used to grasp the clasp at its proximal edge. The bronchoscope and forceps were withdrawn together with the denture fragment intact. Repeat bronchoscopy confirmed no residual foreign material or bleeding. No biopsies, bronchoalveolar lavage, or other therapeutic procedures were performed.
Findings: Inorganic metallic denture fragment in the right lower lobe basal segment bronchus, completely removed; mucosa mildly erythematous.
Complications: None beyond transient cough. No desaturation or hemodynamic instability.
Disposition: Admitted overnight to the medical floor for observation given baseline COPD; no further respiratory compromise.
Impression: Inorganic foreign body aspiration (denture fragment) status post complete removal via flexible bronchoscopy.

bullets: Case documents flexible bronchoscopy with forceps extraction of an inorganic denture fragment from the right lower lobe without additional diagnostic or therapeutic bronchoscopic procedures.
Fluoroscopy is inherent to the 31635 service when used to support foreign body localization and extraction and does not generate a separate imaging CPT.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Rigid bronchoscopy with foreign body removal.
Indication: Pediatric patient with suspected coin aspiration and unilateral wheeze.
Patient: 5-year-old male with acute onset coughing and left-sided wheeze after putting coins in his mouth; CXR with radiopaque density in left mainstem bronchus and hyperinflated left lung.
Sedation/airway: General anesthesia with rigid bronchoscope used as the airway; jet ventilation.
Procedure description: After anesthesia induction and muscle relaxation, a pediatric rigid bronchoscope was introduced through the mouth under direct visualization. The vocal cords and trachea were normal. At the left mainstem bronchus, a circular metallic foreign body consistent with a coin was lodged against the bronchial wall, nearly occluding the lumen. Multiple attempts were required to obtain a secure purchase using rigid optical grasping forceps. The coin was rotated into a favorable orientation and removed en bloc through the rigid bronchoscope. The left bronchial tree was reinspected and was free of additional foreign material. There was minimal mucosal abrasion and no active bleeding. No lavage, biopsy, or other interventions were performed.
Findings: Single metallic coin in the left mainstem bronchus causing near-complete obstruction; completely removed with rigid bronchoscopy.
Complications: None. No significant desaturation or arrhythmia.
Disposition: Admitted to pediatric floor for overnight observation and bronchodilator as needed.
Impression: Pediatric metallic foreign body aspiration status post successful rigid bronchoscopic removal.

bullets: Rigid bronchoscopy with complete removal of a coin from the left mainstem bronchus matches 31635.
There is no airway tumor destruction, stent placement, lavage, or sampling to support additional bronchoscopic CPT codes.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Navigational bronchoscopy with microwave ablation of a peripheral right upper lobe nodule.
Indication: 2.1 cm PET-avid peripheral right upper lobe nodule in a patient with presumed early-stage non-small cell lung cancer who is a poor surgical candidate.
Patient: 74-year-old female with COPD and coronary artery disease.
Sedation/airway: General anesthesia with endotracheal tube.
Procedure description: Following induction of general anesthesia and ETT placement, a flexible bronchoscope was advanced and the tracheobronchial tree inspected. Using electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy, a steerable catheter was guided to a posterior segment right upper lobe peripheral target along a planned pathway. Radial EBUS was then deployed through the extended working channel, demonstrating a concentric ultrasound signal consistent with an in-lesion position. After confirming catheter position with cone-beam CT, the radial EBUS probe was removed and a microwave ablation catheter was advanced to the lesion. A single ablation cycle was performed at 65 W for 7 minutes. Real-time impedance changes and post-ablation cone-beam CT demonstrated an ablation zone encompassing the nodule with at least a 5 mm circumferential margin. The catheter and bronchoscope were removed. No biopsies or lavage were performed during this session.
Findings: Posterior segment right upper lobe peripheral nodule successfully targeted and treated with bronchoscopic microwave ablation; no endobronchial tumor in central airways.
Complications: None. No pneumothorax or significant bleeding identified on immediate post-procedure imaging.
Disposition: Extubated in the procedure suite and recovered in PACU; planned overnight observation on telemetry.
Impression: Peripheral right upper lobe malignant-appearing nodule treated with navigation-guided bronchoscopic microwave ablation.

registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Peripheral right upper lobe malignant-appearing nodule treated with microwave ablation
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Overnight observation with chest X-ray; interval CT chest in 4–6 weeks and multidisciplinary tumor board review

financial_analysis.notes: Total facility RVUs and payment reflect 31641, 31627, and 31654 billed together for one peripheral ablation session.

bullets: Microwave ablation of a peripheral lung nodule via bronchoscopy, without excision language, supports use of 31641 (ablation/destruction).
Electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy is documented to reach the peripheral target, supporting 31627.
Radial EBUS was used for peripheral lesion localization in a single lobe, which supports add-on code 31654.
No biopsies or additional bronchoscopic procedures are described, so no other bronchoscopy CPT codes are added.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Navigational bronchoscopy with radiofrequency ablation of a peripheral right lower lobe nodule.
Indication: 2.0 cm peripheral right lower lobe nodule, biopsy-proven adenocarcinoma, in a patient with limited pulmonary reserve.
Patient: 66-year-old male with GOLD III COPD.
Sedation/airway: General anesthesia with endotracheal tube.
Procedure description: After induction of general anesthesia and ETT placement, flexible bronchoscopy was performed to survey the central airways, which were free of endobronchial tumor. A navigation catheter was advanced using CT-based virtual bronchoscopy planning to a superior segment right lower lobe target. Radial EBUS confirmed an eccentric but in-branch image corresponding to the lesion. The catheter position was refined and rechecked. A radiofrequency ablation catheter was then advanced through the extended working channel to the lesion. Three overlapping ablation cycles (each 50 W for 5 minutes) were delivered with careful monitoring of impedance and tip temperature, reaching approximately 105 °C. Post-ablation cone-beam CT demonstrated an ablation zone encompassing the nodule. No biopsies or additional sampling were performed during this session.
Findings: Peripheral superior segment right lower lobe malignant nodule treated with radiofrequency ablation; no significant central airway pathology.
Complications: None. No pneumothorax, significant hemorrhage, or sustained hypoxia.
Disposition: Extubated and monitored in PACU before overnight admission for observation.
Impression: Peripheral right lower lobe adenocarcinoma treated with navigation-guided bronchoscopic radiofrequency ablation.

bullets: Radiofrequency ablation of a peripheral lung nodule via bronchoscopy appropriately maps to 31641 rather than excisional code 31640.
Electromagnetic navigation is clearly documented, supporting add-on navigation code 31627.
Radial EBUS is described for peripheral lesion localization, supporting add-on code 31654.
No biopsies or lavage are performed during this dedicated ablation session, so sampling codes are not added.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Navigational bronchoscopy with cryoablation of a peripheral left lower lobe nodule.
Indication: 1.4 cm peripheral left lower lobe pulmonary nodule with intermediate PET uptake in a patient with prior contralateral lobectomy.
Patient: 59-year-old female with history of right upper lobectomy for NSCLC and reduced pulmonary reserve.
Sedation/airway: General anesthesia with endotracheal tube.
Procedure description: Under general anesthesia, a flexible bronchoscope was advanced via endotracheal tube and the central airways inspected. Using CT-based navigational bronchoscopy, a steerable catheter was guided to a lateral basal segment left lower lobe target. Radial EBUS confirmed a concentric image consistent with an in-lesion position. A dedicated endobronchial cryoprobe was advanced through the extended working channel into the lesion. Three freeze–thaw cycles were performed (10-minute freeze followed by passive thaw for each cycle), with probe temperatures reaching approximately −60 °C. Cone-beam CT after the final cycle demonstrated an ice ball encompassing the nodule with appropriate margins. No biopsies or lavage were performed in this session.
Findings: 1.4 cm peripheral left lower lobe nodule treated with bronchoscopic cryoablation; no central airway tumor.
Complications: None. No pneumothorax or significant bleeding on post-procedure imaging.
Disposition: Extubated and monitored in PACU, then admitted overnight for observation given limited lung reserve.
Impression: Peripheral left lower lobe nodule treated with navigation-guided bronchoscopic cryoablation.

bullets: Cryoablation of a peripheral lung nodule via bronchoscopy falls under bronchoscopic tumor destruction/ablation (31641).
Computer-assisted navigation to reach a peripheral target supports 31627.
Radial EBUS documentation for peripheral lesion confirmation supports add-on 31654.
No separate sampling procedures (biopsy, brushing, BAL) are documented, so only the ablation and guidance codes are reported.
